articles.headline: Resisting the Urge to Run Away From Home
articles.snippet: Scaling back on stocks in countries with economic woes might be tempting, but few knee-jerk investing strategies born in uncertain times prove wise.
articles.abstract: Scaling back on stocks in countries with economic woes might be tempting, but few knee-jerk investing strategies born in uncertain times prove wise.
articles.lead_paragraph: In market moments like these, it’s always tempting do something really big and bold with our investments.

articles.headline: Officers Guilty of Shooting Six in New Orleans
articles.snippet: Two people were killed in the shootings, which happened on Danziger Bridge in New Orleans while the city’s streets were still flooded.
articles.abstract: Two people were killed in the shootings, which happened on Danziger Bridge in New Orleans while the city’s streets were still flooded.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In a verdict that brought a decisive close to a case that has haunted this city since most of it lay underwater nearly six years ago, five current and former New Orleans police officers were found guilty on all counts by a federal jury on Friday for shooting six citizens, two of whom died, and orchestrating a wide-ranging cover-up in the hours, weeks and years that followed.

articles.headline: Euro Builder Ends His Career on a Bitter Note
articles.snippet: Recent days have highlighted what some critics say are policy mistakes by Jean-Claude Trichet, or at least the institution he leads, the European Central Bank.
articles.abstract: Recent days have highlighted what some critics say are policy mistakes by Jean-Claude Trichet, or at least the institution he leads, the European Central Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, has spent much of his career building and defending the euro. But now, in a bitter twist, it looks as if his career may well end with the common currency in shambles.

articles.headline: Group of 7 Will Meet to Address Debt Issue
articles.snippet: As European leaders on Friday tried to calm debt fears, Italy’s prime minister said finance ministers from the Group of 7 industrial nations would meet “within days.”
articles.abstract: As European leaders on Friday tried to calm debt fears, Italy’s prime minister said finance ministers from the Group of 7 industrial nations would meet “within days.”
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As European leaders on Friday tried to calm fears that the region’s sovereign debt problems were spinning beyond politicians’ control, Italy’s prime minister said finance ministers from the Group of 7 industrial nations would meet “within days” to discuss the volatile financial crisis.

articles.headline: A Murdoch’s Missed Opportunity
articles.snippet: James Murdoch might have spared himself some embarrassment if he had paid the legal fees for an investigator accused in the phone hacking scandal.
articles.abstract: James Murdoch might have spared himself some embarrassment if he had paid the legal fees for an investigator accused in the phone hacking scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the News Corporation announced it would stop paying the legal fees for Glenn Mulcaire, the private investigator at the center of Britain’s tabloid phone hacking scandal, the consequences were swift. Mr. Mulcaire could obviously shed light on who at the News Corporation knew about the phone hacking and efforts to conceal it.

articles.headline: S.& P. Downgrades Debt Rating of U.S. for the First Time
articles.snippet: Standard & Poor’s removed the United States government from its list of risk-free borrowers, dropping the rating on concerns about federal debt.
articles.abstract: Standard & Poor’s removed the United States government from its list of risk-free borrowers, dropping the rating on concerns about federal debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standard & Poor’s removed the United States government from its list of risk-free borrowers for the first time on Friday night, a downgrade that is freighted with symbolic significance but carries few clear financial implications.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In Tunisian Town of Arab Spring Martyr, Disillusionment Seeps In
articles.snippet: The government has moved slowly to address one of the revolution’s central complaints — youth unemployment — especially in the towns where the uprising began.
articles.abstract: The government has moved slowly to address one of the revolution’s central complaints — youth unemployment — especially in the towns where the uprising began.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIDI BOUZID, Tunisia — It is hard to say for sure who took down the portrait of the revolution’s most famous martyr, Mohamed Bouazizi, from its perch atop a garish gold statue on the street where he set himself on fire, touching off a season of revolt across the Arab world. One man said unnamed counterrevolutionaries did it, and another man said it was damaged by rain.

articles.headline: Ex-Lawmaker Still a Friend of Hospitals
articles.snippet: Former Representative Earl Pomeroy’s partnership with an aide helps him avoid restrictions on lobbying after leaving Congress.
articles.abstract: Former Representative Earl Pomeroy’s partnership with an aide helps him avoid restrictions on lobbying after leaving Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Earl Pomeroy figured that Plan A was his career in Congress, where, over nearly two decades, as a North Dakota congressman he became a powerful advocate for the hospital industry.

articles.headline: Copter Downed by Taliban Fire; Elite U.S. Unit Among Dead
articles.snippet: Among the dead were elite Navy Seal commandos from the broader unit that killed Osama bin Laden in Pakistan, though none were involved in that raid.
articles.abstract: Among the dead were elite Navy Seal commandos from the broader unit that killed Osama bin Laden in Pakistan, though none were involved in that raid.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  Ray Rivera,  Alissa J. Rubin and  Thom Shanker.
articles.byline: By Ray Rivera, Alissa J. Rubin and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Amid Criticism on Downgrade of U.S., S.&P. Fires Back
articles.snippet: A day after Standard & Poor’s downgraded the creditworthiness of the United States government, it defended its decision and warned that further downgrades may come.
articles.abstract: A day after Standard & Poor’s downgraded the creditworthiness of the United States government, it defended its decision and warned that further downgrades may come.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day after Standard & Poor’s took the unprecedented step of stripping the United States government of its top credit rating, the ratings agency offered a full-throated defense of its decision, calling the bitter stand-off between President Obama and Congress over raising the debt ceiling a “debacle.” It warned that further downgrades may lie ahead.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Pressing All the Buttons for a Panic Attack
articles.snippet: Many experts say the 2008 financial collapse recalibrated investor psychology so that now some are apt to sell first and ask questions later.
articles.abstract: Many experts say the 2008 financial collapse recalibrated investor psychology so that now some are apt to sell first and ask questions later.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRADLEY ALFORD, a money manager in Atlanta, just hit the panic button.

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Tax on Main Street
articles.snippet: Banks have peddled all sorts of complex financing to state and local governments, and some of the deals have become costly mistakes.
articles.abstract: Banks have peddled all sorts of complex financing to state and local governments, and some of the deals have become costly mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMID all the talk of debt and default in Washington last week, tiny Central Falls, R.I., went bankrupt.

articles.headline: Would You Like a Smile With That?
articles.snippet: Using an offbeat take on fast-food service — and employee motivation — the Pret a Manger chain is gaining an American foothold.
articles.abstract: Using an offbeat take on fast-food service — and employee motivation — the Pret a Manger chain is gaining an American foothold.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOMETHING weird is happening inside a Pret a Manger sandwich shop on Broadway in Midtown Manhattan.

articles.headline: Markets Expected Credit Ruling, but Risks Remain, Analysts Say
articles.snippet: With the United States economy on such fragile footing, anything that undermines already low confidence levels could create a ripple effect and further stall the recovery.
articles.abstract: With the United States economy on such fragile footing, anything that undermines already low confidence levels could create a ripple effect and further stall the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hit to the United States’ prized credit rating may have arrived with a jolt Friday, but many analysts say it’s not so clear that it will deliver any immediate shock to financial markets or to consumers. That is because it confirmed what the markets, economists and most people already know: the United States has a debt problem and Washington is deeply divided over how to solve it.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: U.S. Widens Role in Battle Against Mexican Drug Cartels
articles.snippet: Mexican and U.S. officials said that new efforts have been designed to get around Mexican laws that prohibit foreign military and police from operating on its soil.
articles.abstract: Mexican and U.S. officials said that new efforts have been designed to get around Mexican laws that prohibit foreign military and police from operating on its soil.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is expanding its role in Mexico’s bloody fight against drug trafficking organizations, sending new C.I.A. operatives and retired military personnel to the country and considering plans to deploy private security contractors in hopes of  turning around a multibillion-dollar effort that so far has shown few results.

articles.headline: Syrian Military Mounts Assault on Another City
articles.snippet: The Syrian military defied growing condemnation and deployed tanks in the restive Deir al-Zour, killing dozens, activists said.
articles.abstract: The Syrian military defied growing condemnation and deployed tanks in the restive Deir al-Zour, killing dozens, activists said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian military defied growing condemnation and initiated another assault on the country’s most restive locales on Sunday, deploying dozens of tanks and armored vehicles into parts of a city in eastern Syria that it had long feared provoking, activists and residents said. Dozens were killed, they said, and thousands had fled the city.

articles.headline: Global Finance Leaders Pledge Bold Action to Calm Markets
articles.snippet: The European Central Bank said it would intervene in bond markets; Group of 7 finance officials said they would take “all necessary measures” to support stability.
articles.abstract: The European Central Bank said it would intervene in bond markets; Group of 7 finance officials said they would take “all necessary measures” to support stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank signaled on Sunday that it would intervene more aggressively in bond markets to protect Spain and Italy, and leading finance ministers conferred about the mounting threats to the world’s economies, as policy makers sought to calm markets unnerved by deteriorating public finances and slow economic growth.

articles.headline: Second Recession in U.S. Could Be Worse Than First
articles.snippet: Policy makers exhausted their resources in the last recession and, in a weaker economy, would have few options the next time.
articles.abstract: Policy makers exhausted their resources in the last recession and, in a weaker economy, would have few options the next time.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the economy falls back into recession, as many economists are now warning, the bloodletting could be a lot more painful than the last time around.

articles.headline: News Corp.’s Soft Power in the U.S.
articles.snippet: A division of the News Corporation has twice come under investigations in the United States, but neither went anywhere.
articles.abstract: A division of the News Corporation has twice come under investigations in the United States, but neither went anywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last month, many Americans watched from a distance in horror or amusement as it became evident that the News Corporation regarded Britain’s legal and political institutions as its own private club.

articles.headline: Shopper Receipts Join Paperless Age
articles.snippet: Major retailers have begun offering electronic versions, either e-mailed or uploaded to password-protected Web sites, and customers are increasingly receptive to the idea.
articles.abstract: Major retailers have begun offering electronic versions, either e-mailed or uploaded to password-protected Web sites, and customers are increasingly receptive to the idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: At an Old Navy store in Manhattan the other day, Fabienne Michel made a routine purchase of khaki shorts. But she left the store without something equally routine: her receipt.

articles.headline: Ad Money Reliably Goes to Television
articles.snippet: The overall economy is muddling, but the tried-and-true commercial continues to draw merchandisers.
articles.abstract: The overall economy is muddling, but the tried-and-true commercial continues to draw merchandisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy is faltering and consumers are scared, but you wouldn’t know it by watching television, where advertisers are still pouring in money.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: Across Globe, Traders Brace for a Downturn
articles.snippet: Shock waves from the downgrade of the United States credit rating hit global markets over the weekend and traders on Wall St. prepared their strategy.
articles.abstract: Shock waves from the downgrade of the United States credit rating hit global markets over the weekend and traders on Wall St. prepared their strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Traders and bankers are braced for another volatile week in global markets — and the wildest ride is likely to be in stocks, not the Treasury bonds that were downgraded by Standard & Poor’s on Friday.

articles.headline: Huntsman Runs on His Name, and His Father’s
articles.snippet: Some wonder if, in pursuing the presidency, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is chasing his father’s dream. He says he is pursuing nobody’s dream but his own.
articles.abstract: Some wonder if, in pursuing the presidency, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is chasing his father’s dream. He says he is pursuing nobody’s dream but his own.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Jon M. Huntsman Jr. was 10 years old when his father packed up their growing family to move east in 1970, leaving behind his fledgling company to work for President Richard M. Nixon.

articles.headline: Sharp Rift in a Strike at Verizon
articles.snippet: The striking workers are mostly in Verizon’s declining wireline businesses, but also in its popular FiOS service. The company remains highly profitable.
articles.abstract: The striking workers are mostly in Verizon’s declining wireline businesses, but also in its popular FiOS service. The company remains highly profitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decision by 45,000 workers at Verizon Communications businesses to go on strike Sunday over proposed benefit cuts reflects sharp battle lines. On one side is a highly profitable telecommunications company that is eager to trim costs in its declining businesses; on the other are unionized workers who fear that the many concessions demanded by their employer will force them to give up decades of hard-won gains.

articles.headline: China’s Premier Seeks Reforms and Relevance
articles.snippet: Wen Jiabao, the prime minister of China and the leading supporter of what passes for political liberalism in the country, appears increasingly marginalized.
articles.abstract: Wen Jiabao, the prime minister of China and the leading supporter of what passes for political liberalism in the country, appears increasingly marginalized.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by  Jonathan Ansfield,  Michael Wines and  Sharon LaFraniere and written by Mr. Wines.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines, Jonathan Ansfield and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Stocks Suffer Sharpest Drop Since 2008
articles.snippet: Stocks fell sharply Monday as investors, already worried about the economy, worked out the downgrade’s implications. Bank stocks, in particular, were hammered.
articles.abstract: Stocks fell sharply Monday as investors, already worried about the economy, worked out the downgrade’s implications. Bank stocks, in particular, were hammered.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market resumed its free fall Monday on mounting fears about the stalling economy and worries that the government had few options to increase growth, dual concerns that overshadowed the downgrade of long-term United States government debt.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Sues Bank of America Over Mortgage Bonds
articles.snippet: The suit seeks to recover more than $10 billion in losses on mortgage-backed securities, claiming Bank of America and its affiliates misrepresented the quality of the underlying mortgages.
articles.abstract: The suit seeks to recover more than $10 billion in losses on mortgage-backed securities, claiming Bank of America and its affiliates misrepresented the quality of the underlying mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group sued Bank of America on Monday over hundreds of mortgage-backed securities, adding to the surge of investors seeking compensation for the troubled mortgages that led to the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Rioting Widens in London on 3rd Night of Unrest
articles.snippet: Rioting and looting spread to at least eight areas and broke out for the first time in another big city.
articles.abstract: Rioting and looting spread to at least eight areas and broke out for the first time in another big city.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The rioting and looting that convulsed poorer sections of London over the weekend spread Monday to at least eight new districts in the metropolitan area and broke out for the first time in Britain’s second-largest city, Birmingham, in what was developing into the worst outbreak of social unrest in Britain in 25 years.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya and John F. Burns
